utterance: Charles McCrory: I I think there there are sort of two things that I think are really interesting in sort of moving um sort of this uh one would be um I'm really interested in the idea of vapor vapor-fed catalysis uh for CO2 reduction so that you can you can work at steam temperatures to accelerate the kinetics of CO2. Um what that does to reaction distributions and product distributions I don't know. Um and then so you use a porous um a porous membrane or polymer to wick water from steam and use that as your proton source in the catalytic process. Um and then the other thing just in general is this idea of using overlayers or polymers to control delivery but also control the secondary coordination sphere either in heterogeneous solid state systems, nanoparticle systems or molecular systems. Of course that's what I work on so of course I care about that but that's the other big thing that I think is is underexplored in this area.

utterance: Christopher Gorski: Well I mean I guess I'm thinking about I'm not a material scientist. I'm just thinking about this more broadly in terms of what the goals are. And that when we do CO2 capture people usually report energy demand associated with it but there's obviously other metrics, the rate at which you capture it, the purity of you're getting, how deep you capture from. And then also with conversion then it's the purity of what you're making, the value of what you're making. And I'm just sort of struggling to figure out like we can develop new materials but beyond just like a trial and error of improving those materials like what metric are you actually aiming for? Is it higher selectivity? Is it the energy that you need to put in to make that product? So I'm trying to wrap my head around that.

annotations.ask question: Christopher Gorski is asking questions about the goals and metrics for CO2 capture and conversion, seeking clarity on what they are aiming for.

utterance: Charles McCrory: Yeah Gary probably could could could really chime in on here too. From my perspective release when you're going to capture CO2 and release it to a conversion technology. From my perspective it's not necessarily the concentration of CO2, it's the concentration of oxygen. Oxygen is your killer for any conversion technology because you will always preferentially reduce oxygen. So if you can separate CO2 from oxygen that's like the key. And that's I know it's hard to do certainly with membranes and polymers that's like impossible right but but not impossible but it's very hard to do. Ionic liquids can do it but separating that CO2 from oxygen because you can do if you have reaction selectivity if you can engineer that into your system through microenvironments or catalyst design then even if you have dilute CO2 streams feeding in probably needs to be more concentrated than 300 ppm but but if you have dilute CO2 streams feeding in you can drive the catalysis albeit slowly and the conversion without a lot of competitive processes but if you have any O2 you just won't do any CO2 reduction you'll only do O2 reduction. That's my on that aspect. And in terms of CO2 I think it's all the overpotential you need to get to reasonable rates it's it's the energy conversion efficiency. There was an interesting in the last session we just talked about there was a big discussion the last breakout session on on CO2 reduction in general the big discussion was catalysts don't usually catalyst costs usually don't matter because membranes out balance of systems and membranes are the big cost driver but energy efficiency sort of does. And we don't have any electrocatalysts that operate at good potentials versus thermodynamic potential. Okay I'll. Anyway that's just my view though you know other people should.
